Add assertions to verify assumptions at several places
commitResults.messageBody:
The Duke.createTask() method may return null due to the default switch
case. This may cause errors in other parts of the code if a null value
is inserted as a Task in the TaskList.

Let's use an assertion to verify that the caller of createTask() doesn't
receive a null value by accident.

When removing a Task in the Duke.deleteTask() method, we do not check
if a null value is returned by the TaskList.removeTask() method. This
may cause an error when generating the corresponding UI messages if a
null value is used.

Let's use an assertion to verify that the returned Task object is not
null.

The String argument of the Duke.getResponse() method may be null due to
some error in the GUI classes/code. This will cause errors in other
parts of the code if a null value is used as user input.

Let's use an assertion to verify that the given String argument is not
null.

commitResults.messageTitle: Refactor the Duke.createTask() method by extracting out the code to create each type of task into separate helper methods.
commitResults.messageBody:
The createTask() method is too long due to the code to create each type
of task. This makes the entire method hard to read and debug.

Let's extract out the code to create each type of task (Todo, Deadline
and Event) into separate helper methods. This greatly shortens the
createTask() method, making it easier to read. Furthermore, future
changes in how a task is created can now be applied to the specific
type of task instead of affecting the entire createTask() method.
